The field of internal medicine known as nephrology is a specialization that focuses on the identification and management of kidney-related illnesses. The kidneys are the bean-shaped organs that are positioned on either side in the retroperitoneal area in a human body. The kidneys are in charge of eliminating waste and extra fluid from the body. They are essential for maintaining electrolyte concentrations, which might fluctuate due to a variety of illnesses or medications, and for maintaining fluid consumption.Many renal issues are systemic illnesses, meaning they affect more than just the kidney. These ailments require specific care and medical attention.

Patients with a range of acute and chronic renal illnesses can receive comprehensive care from the Nephrology Division at Hope Hospitals. As one of the top kidney hospitals in India, we are famous for utilizing cutting-edge resources and therapies. Through a variety of non-invasive procedures, the nephrology specialists continuously devote time, energy, and experience to assisting people in maintaining the health of their kidneys.

Why choose Hope Hospitals Nephrology?

Our staff of skilled nephrologists is recognized for its exceptional clinical abilities and for giving adults and children of all ages top-notch care.For all nephrology diseases, we provide cutting-edge diagnostics, all-encompassing care, and the best nephrology therapies.

The latest medical equipment is well-equipped in the labs, wards, and operating rooms, and the facility has been designed to make patients feel at ease while receiving treatment.

Kidney conditions we treat

  • Electrolyte imbalance
  • Alport syndrome
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Kidney stones
  • Fabry’s disease
  • Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD)

Services we provide for Nephrology

  • Acute kidney damage management Consistent 24/7 hemodialysis 
  • Separate dialysis units and isolation areas for patients who are HBsAg and HCV positive 
  • All resources available to research, identify, treat, and prevent chronic kidney disease in both adults and children 
  • Plasmapheresis for neurological and renal 
  • Individualized care for kidney stones and polycystic kidney disease 
  • Ultrasonic kidney biopsy during percutaneous biopsy
  •  Intensive care unit patients receiving hemodialysis at their bedsides 
  • Nephrotic syndrome and other glomerulonephritis treatment 
  • Sustained low efficiency daily dialysis (SLEDD) 
  • Control of primary and secondary hypertension

Treatments we offer for Kidney conditions

Medications

Our medical professionals collaborate with you to manage renal issues using various sorts of drugs. These could consist of vitamins, dietary supplements, or medications for high blood pressure. Drugs may be required if you have kidney stones in order to help you pass the stones.

Kidney Transplant

Dialysis or a kidney transplant are required for patients with renal failure. Patients must frequently travel to a dialysis facility for treatment, which takes time. However, with a liver transplant, patients can enjoy a higher quality of life and are not as dependent on a dialysis machine.

Dialysis

We provide both inpatient and outpatient dialysis. A specialized device filters and eliminates waste from your blood during hemodialysis. The lining of your abdomen is used in peritoneal dialysis to filter blood while it is still inside your body. We also provide continuous renal replacement therapy, a continuous blood-filtering dialysis that runs around the clock.

Minimally invasive treatment

We are experts in a number of techniques for dissolving or removing kidney stones. Small incisions or nonsurgical shock wave technologies are used during these treatments, which shorten the recuperation period.

Diet and lifestyle changes

Our nephrology specialists and dietitians assist you in making wiser decisions through education, nutritional counseling, and support. Our aim is to give you the resources you need to take charge of your health.

Liver dialysis (MARS therapy)

The Molecular Adsorbent Recirculating System, often known as MARS therapy, effectively removes the protein-bound and water-soluble toxins by using the albumin dialysis principle as its foundation. The medical method could promote liver regeneration and stabilize the functions of key organs.

Hemodialysis:

Hemodialysis is a specialized procedure that removes extra waste, moisture, and chemicals from the blood before reintroducing it to the body. It uses an artificial kidney device called a hemodialyzer. Through a catheter or port inserted into a leg, arm, or neck after purification, blood is returned to the body.

Patients who have renal failure that has progressed to its last stage frequently have this treatment. A patient needs around four hours of hemodialysis sessions three times per week at this level since their kidneys no longer function between 85 and 90% of the time.

Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy (CRRT)

Critically ill patients typically have a high metabolic rate because their bodies are working hard to recover from the illness. They also require substantial amounts of fluid in the form of nutritional and inotropic agents, pharmacological infusions, and constant waste disposal. As a result, CRRT, or continuous renal replacement therapy, is used to gently eliminate wastes and water without resulting in hypotension.In CRRT, the blood is drawn out and pumped through a hemofilter in a slow kind of hemodialysis.

 

When is it necessary to see a nephrologist?

A general practitioner may be able to prevent and cure early kidney disease. Kidney illnesses often have no or vague symptoms. Fatigue, urinary changes, and sleep issues are examples.Thus, high-risk individuals must have regular kidney tests to evaluate their health and function. Diabetics, heart disease, high blood pressure, and kidney disease families should be cautious.

Regular tests can reveal renal function declines such as urine albumin increases or GFR decreases. See a nephrologist if tests suggest your kidney functions are rapidly declining.

 

What function does dialysis serve?

Dialysis guarantees the body’s regular operation by

  • Maintaining healthy blood pressure levels
  • Removing salt and trash to keep the body from becoming clogged
  • Maintain healthy levels of sodium, potassium, and bicarbonate in the body.

 

What triggers kidney illnesses?

Kidney disease has two primary causes: diabetes and high blood pressure. Other potential contributing variables outside of this include genetic kidney conditions such as polycystic kidney disease .

Your key body organs, including the heart, brain, and kidneys, suffer blood vessel damage as a result of high blood pressure, commonly known as hypertension. However, if you already have a renal illness, it might make the high blood pressure condition even worse and more deadly.

 

What is the role of a nephrologist?

Doctors with a focus on the kidneys or disorders related to the kidneys are known as nephrologists. Nephrologists address conditions like kidney cancer, high blood pressure, autoimmune diseases, diabetic nephropathy, and other related issues

 

When is hemodialysis required?

When a patient reaches the latter stage of renal failure, dialysis is required. At this point, a person typically loses 85 to 90 percent of renal function, and their GFR drops below 15.

 

Does a nephrologist perform surgery?

Patients who have issues with their kidneys or particular types of metabolic illnesses are seen by nephrologists. To find out how well their kidneys are working, they examine their blood and urine. To gain a clearer understanding of the diseases, they could occasionally also request an ultrasound or a kidney biopsy.

However, nephrologists rarely carry out such operations. Urologists typically undertake operations and surgery to treat various kidney problems.
